Dear Ms. Hardin:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on April 2, 2018
thru April 4, 2018, April 9, 2018 and May 2, 2018 and May 3, 2018. Due to the violations
of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and requirements, a written
corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules
are also violations of the Implementation Sustainability and Exit Plan(ISEP) and your
contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must
include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or ISEP citation.
 An explanation why previous corrective action plans have not
obtained and maintained compliance for rules found in repeat
noncompliance.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12209 Orientation and training.
(1) An agency shall ensure and document that each social
service worker and each social service supervisor receives not
less than 16 hours of orientation after initial appointment and
before assumption of assigned duties.
Two of eight new employee records reviewed did not show
documentation of 16 hours of orientation as required by the rule.
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(3) The personnel record shall contain both of the following:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member's performance
within a probationary period or not later than 6 months after the
staff member assumes his or her current responsibilities. After
the initial evaluation, a written evaluation shall be conducted
each year.
One of twelve employee records reviewed showed the
employee’s annual evaluation was twenty-two days late.
Repeat Violation- Renewal 2017.
R400.12312 Foster parent training.
(4) At least 1 adult member of the household shall have training
in and maintain a current certification in first aid from the
American Heart Association or the American Red Cross or other
institution approved by the department.
One of six open foster home records reviewed showed the
foster parent’s first aid certification expired 3/16/2017.

(3) Except for an original license, an agency shall recommend to

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were one incident of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during this
licensing period.
This incident related to an initial allegation related to the foster parent having
insufficient income. During the investigation a second complaint surfaced that the
foster parent/relative had assaulted another relative in the present of the children. A
knife which the foster parent/relative reported normally carrying on her person was
involved and fell on the floor. During the investigation It was revealed the foster
parent/relative had physically disciplined the children, by use of her hand or a back
scratcher. The foster parent/caregiver admitted to a physical fight with her relative
but denied ever hitting the children with anything.
The foster home was found in violation of foster home rules, inclusive of the foster
parent qualifications rule and behavior management rules. Revocation of the foster
home license was recommended. The agency appeared to have acted appropriately
related the incident; and except for R400.12327(1)(a), for which the agency received a
citation, the agency adhered to timeframes and standard related to the special
evaluation.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period. However, there were two incidents of behavioral management violations.
The first incident related to an allegation that the foster parent called the foster child
dumb and retarded. The children in the home reported the foster father was calling
the foster child(ren), dumb, dumbo, retarded and idiots. The foster father admitted to
calling the children dumb and dumbo’s, but stated he never meant the names he
used in a malicious manner. A corrective action plan was developed with the foster
home that entailed a re-review/signing of the agency’s behavior management policy.
Additionally, the foster parents were to complete a training titled Sensible discipline.
The foster parents were also required to complete a quiz at the end of the training
and submit it to the agency’s licensing department.
The second incident related to an allegation that foster mother was advised what to
say to get a foster child removed from her home. Additionally, that the foster mother
was separating a previous foster child off from the foster father, whom the foster
child was close to, due to the foster parents’ adopted child feeling left out. Further,
that the foster mother was mean, would yell a lot at that foster child and send him to
his room. There special evaluation found insufficient evidence to support the
allegations. Yet during the special evaluation it was revealed the foster parents
utilized inappropriate discipline. “Daddy time out” was used, which involved the
foster parent placing a leg over the child, as if to restraint the child. The foster
13

parents were also calling a foster child a name other than her birth name, after the
foster care worker had instructed them not to on two separation occasions. The
foster parents were found in violation of the behavior management policy and foster
parent qualification related to a willingness and ability to comply with licensing rules.
A corrective action plan was developed with the foster parents that entailed the
foster parent re-reviewing/signing the agency’s behavior management policy.
The agency appeared to have acted appropriately related to these incidents and
adhered to Departmental timeframes related to special evaluations. However, the
agency received violations related to R400.12327(6)(c) and (7) as documented
earlier in this report. Technical assistance and consultation was also provided
related to R400.12327, as indicated above.
The agency has submitted three acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
The first corrective action plan related to the agency’s Renewal Inspection, where it
received several rules, ISEP and policy violations. Despite a reduction in the
number of violations cited in this Interim Inspection report, the agency was not
successful with its corrective action plan as indicated by the number of repeat rule
violations. The agency experienced significant staff changes, since the last
Inspection review. Eight new staff (Two adoption workers, four foster workers and a
licensing worker) came aboard, in addition to them adding a foster care/independent
living supervisor. The agency also acquired a new Chief Executive Officer. The
agency appears hopefully related to maintaining these staff and improving its
performance.
The second corrective action plan related to Special Investigation 2017C0420031,
initiated 5/30/17. The complaint alleged the agency was not conducting proper
FTMs; siblings had not had a visit with one another in four months, and the agency
was not providing correct information to court on the birth mother’s progress, nor
informing the birth mother with information related to her children’s doctor
appointments and therapy referrals. Additionally, that the children’s photographs
were used in the agency newsletter with the foster parent.
The agency was not found in violation of the latter two allegations which pertained to
R400.12207(3)(a) or R400.12211 for Privacy safeguard. The special investigation
found the agency in violation of R400.12421(d) for Visitation and parenting time;
Contract/Policy standard FOM 722-6B for Family Team Meetings; and FOM 722-6 H
for Casework contacts. The agency submitted an acceptable corrective action plan
on 8/17/17. The agency was not totally successful with this corrective action plan, in
that it received a citation related to FOM 722-6B this Interim Inspection.
The third corrective action plan related to Special Investigation 2017C0420049,
initiated 7/25/17. The complaint alleged the agency allowed the foster parents to
baptize the foster children without a written consent from the birth parent. The
special investigation substantiated the allegation and the agency was found in
14

violation of R 400.12314 for Religion policy. The agency submitted an acceptable
corrective action plan on 10/2/17, which indicated the agency’s policy was updated
to ensure written consent is received from biological parents before allowing a foster
parent to baptize a foster child. Additionally, that all staff were apprised of the
updated policy.
The agency remains incompliance with this corrective action plan.
BCAL ANALYST CONCERNS:
-Concern: The foster care worker has only made an unannounced home visit to the
foster home once or twice a year.
Resolution: The case record showed required quarterly unannounced foster home
visits were not documented/completed as required by policy. The agency received a
citation for MDHHS (Michigan Department of Health and Humans Services) policy 722-
6H for Unannounced home visits. The agency will provide a corrective action plan to
address this issue.
Concern: The foster parent did not receive the medical passport.
Resolution: MISACWIS documented that the foster parent received the medical
passport after the child’s initial placement on 4/7/15. Four unsigned medical passports
were documented in the MISACWIS record, but verification that the foster received a
copy of the child’s updated medical passports was not. The agency received
a violation under ISEP 6.49 for Medical passport. The agency will provide the foster
parent within an updated medical passport with fifteen days of receipt of this Interim
report. The agency will provide a corrective action plan to address this issue on an
ongoing basis.
Concern: The foster parent has not provided input or signed the treatment plan.
Resolution: Review of the foster child’s service plans indicated input and information
reported by the foster parent. The foster parent signed treatment plans 3/18/17-6/15/17
and 6/16/17- 9/13/17 treatment plan, but not the 9/14/17-12/17 treatment plan. The
agency was cited under MDHHS policy FOM 722-8C for Foster care- Parent Agency
Treatment Plan & Service Agreement. The agency will provide a corrective action plan
addressing this issue.
-Concern: The foster care worker has not made an unannounced home visit since the
child’s placement.

7/22/16. The record documented several foster home visits, since then and two
attempted unannounced foster home visits (5/3/17and 8/3/17). The agency received a
violation under MDHHS policy FOM 722-6H for Unannounced home visits. The agency
will provide a corrective action plan to address this issue.
Concern: The foster parent did not receive the child’s medical passport.
15

this child for years prior to becoming licensed 7/22/16. MISACWIS showed the relative

passports were not documented. Two medical passports were on file (1/20/17, 3/20/18)
that did not show documentation of the foster parent’s signature/ that they were
provided the foster parent. The agency received a violation under ISEP 6.49 for Medical
passports. The agency will provide the relative foster parent with an updated medical
passport within fifteen days of receipt of this Interim report. The agency will provide a
corrective action plan to address this issue on an ongoing basis.
Concern: The foster child has not had monthly visits with other siblings in care.
Resolution: The agency reported the child (age 17) is a permanent ward who does not
have siblings in care. The agency indicated and documentation showed the youth’s two
siblings are in adult foster care placement. The youth ‘s sister was placed with in an
adult foster home 12/8/17, and the youth’s older brother had been in adult placement
since 2016. The youth’s record showed documentation of numerous monthly visitations
by the older two siblings at the foster youth’s foster home. One was not documented for
February 2018, or prior to 3/9/18 which was the period the DCWL Analyst visited the
relative caregivers’ home. A sibling visit was documented for October 2017, November
2017, the USP reported the siblings visited at the holidays. A monthly visit was
documented for 1/13/18 and 3/31/18 respectively. Other monthly sibling visitations were
also documented previously. A rule violation was not cited.

caregiver’s home.

were scheduled. The agency received a violation under MDHHS policy FOM 722-6H for
